channel.title: Indigenous Perspectives
channel.itunes:author: Todd Lyons
channel.itunes:subtitle: Stories from Indigenous public servants
channel.itunes:summary: In their own words, public servants give voice to diverse experiences—and struggles—around what it means to be Indigenous: from being firmly rooted in community, to living in two worlds but belonging in neither. Discussions about the legacies of history, the role of culture in the workplace, and how to move forward on reconciliation shed light on the varied factors that motivate Indigenous people to join, and stay, in the Public Service.

item.title: A Conversation with Candice St-Aubin
item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: A one-on-one conversation with Candice St-Aubin, Director General of Employment and Social Development Canada’s Indigenous Affairs Directorate.
item.itunes:subtitle: A one-on-one conversation with Candice St-Aubin.
item.itunes:author: Todd Lyons
item.itunes:summary: A one-on-one conversation with Candice St-Aubin, Director General of Employment and Social Development Canada’s Indigenous Affairs Directorate.

item.title: Appearances
item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: Public servants share their thoughts and feelings on appearances: the benefits of blending in, the sadness in being shut out, the uncertainty of feeling that you're in two worlds but belong to neither.
item.itunes:subtitle: Public servants share their thoughts and feelings on appearances: the benefits of blending in, the sadness in being shut out, the uncertainty of feeling that you're in two worlds but belong to neither.

item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: Indigenous Perspectives presents a special one-to-one chat with Gina Wilson, Deputy Minister of Status of Women Canada and Champion of Federal Indigenous employees in the Government of Canada.

item.title: Legacy of the Past
item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: On this episode, the thoughts and feelings of some of Canada's own public servants on their past, our collective past, and the path forward.

item.title: Things to Know
item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: On this episode, a completely open question. What is it about you, your community or your culture that you want others to know?
item.itunes:subtitle: A completely open question. What is it about you, your community or your culture that you want others to know?
item.itunes:author: Todd Lyons
item.itunes:summary: On this episode, a completely open question. What is it about you, your community or your culture that you want others to know?

item.title: What is Reconciliation?
item.author: todd@toddlyons.ca (Todd Lyons)
item.description: Indigenous Perspectives, a podcast series created for Employment and Social Development Canada, explores being Indigenous in the Public Service, what reconciliation is for individuals, and what it can be for Canada. In their own words, public servants give voice to diverse experiences—and struggles—around what it means to be Indigenous: from being firmly rooted in community, to living in two worlds but belonging in neither. Discussions about the legacies of history, the role of culture in the workplace, and how to move forward on reconciliation shed light on the varied factors that motivate Indigenous people to join, and stay, in the Public Service. On this episode: what is reconciliation?
item.itunes:subtitle: Indigenous Perspectives, a podcast series I created for Employment and Social Development Canada, explores being Indigenous in the Public Service, what reconciliation is for individuals, and what it can be for Canada.
item.itunes:author: Todd Lyons
item.itunes:summary: Indigenous Perspectives, a podcast series created for Employment and Social Development Canada, explores being Indigenous in the Public Service, what reconciliation is for individuals, and what it can be for Canada. In their own words, public servants give voice to diverse experiences—and struggles—around what it means to be Indigenous: from being firmly rooted in community, to living in two worlds but belonging in neither. Discussions about the legacies of history, the role of culture in the workplace, and how to move forward on reconciliation shed light on the varied factors that motivate Indigenous people to join, and stay, in the Public Service. On this episode: what is reconciliation?
